history.content: You're probably better off posting this on Data 001 Piazza but what I'll say is that just because a class is online doesn't mean it'll have expand indefinitely. While being online means there's no room constraint, the other primary limiting factor ie. staff budget to hire TAs/readers is fixed, and may even be reduced due to lack of funding in the COVID era. As such,I wouldn't expect much of an expansion unless you hear differently from an advisor or professor

children.subject: Speaking from personal experience: Prof. Bamman is generally sympathetic to students who are on the waitlist and trying to get in, esp if they have related interests. Go to every lecture when the class starts and make your presence known in his office hours from day 1, and make your linguistics background known. As long as you're close-ish to the Top 10% waitlist spots and show yourself to be a student who will make the most of the class and will be very engaged, you have a decent shot.

history.content:
My phase 1 isn't until Monday, but the waitlist is already full and the class only has 21 seats left, all reserved for datasci majors. Is it likely given this semester's unique circumstances (remote, so possibly more student capacity) that I can even get onto the waitlist, let alone the class itself? 

I'm planning to check the waitlist status every few days to see if there's an opening because I would really like to take it (as I am a cs-language double major and considering a linguistics minor), but I don't know if there's a point... I'll also be graduating possibly next winter, so if I don't take it this semester and it's not offered in fall, I'll never get to take it, which will be kinda sad given how aligned it is with my interests. Any advice would be appreciated; thank you!
history.subject: getting onto waitlist for info 159 (NLP)
